title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
AstraZeneca's US clinical trial of its Covid-19 vaccine developed with Oxford university has shown 79 per cent efficacy at preventing symptomatic disease and 100 per cent efficacy against severe or critical disease and hospitalisation.

The results are similar to those from other Covid-19 vaccines made by BioNTech/Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson, which have all shown varying degrees of efficacy against symptomatic Covid-19 in trials, but they have all been shown to be highly effective in preventing severe disease and death.

A fifth of the participants in the AstraZeneca trial were over 65 and the jab showed 80 per cent efficacy in these older participants.

The AstraZeneca vaccine is currently the subject of a safety row in Europe, where at least 16 countries have paused or limited its rollout after some recipients developed unusual blood clotting side-effects.

The US trial reviewed blood clotting problems, including cerebral venous sinus thrombosis — a blood clot in the brain — with the assistance of an independent neurologist and found no increased risk of clotting or events characterised by blood clots among the 21,583 participants receiving at least one dose of the vaccine. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The unprecedented effort to manufacture Covid-19 vaccines is disrupting supplies of other critical medicines in the US, including treatments for infectious diseases and injectable drugs that prevent blindness.

  • Miami Beach was under a curfew and a state of emergency after police fired pepper balls to disperse crowds of revellers who defied Covid safety guidelines on Saturday night.

  • Boris Johnson, British prime minister, will this week urge EU national capitals to veto a suggestion from Brussels that would block AstraZeneca vaccine exports to the UK.

  • Slovakia's prime minister said he was ready to stand down to defuse a crisis over his decision to purchase Russia's Sputnik V vaccine, which has not been approved by Europe's regulator.

  • Joe Biden's $1.9tn stimulus promises to propel the global economy towards its pre-pandemic path through increased US demand for foreign-made goods. (FT)

Volunteering, such as at a vaccination centre, can make one happier, healthier and more satisfied with life. Purpose-seeking companies should take note, writes Pilita Clark. Follow our live blog for the latest.

In the news

Leon Black quits senior roles at Apollo Leon Black, who co-founded Apollo Global Management 30 years ago, is to relinquish his leadership positions at the investment firm, following an outcry over his ties to the late paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. Former Securities and Exchange Commission chair Jay Clayton will become non-executive chairman, a role that Apollo had previously indicated that Black intended to keep. (FT)

Turkish lira tumult Turkey's currency tumbled as much as 14 per cent on Monday, following the dismissal of the country's central bank chief over the weekend. Naci Agbal, who was removed from his post in the early hours of Saturday morning, was regarded as crucial to the lira's recovery from historic lows last year. (FT)

US battles migrant surge The top US immigration official on Sunday said authorities were expelling the majority of migrants crossing the southern border as the Biden administration battles a growing political crisis over the surging number of children entering the US. Jude Webber spoke to migrants in Tijuana, Mexico, who hope Joe Biden will let them in. The FT View is that the president must risk upsetting his party to control migration. (FT)

Railroad deal is the biggest of the year Canadian Pacific has agreed to buy Kansas City Southern for $28.9bn, including debt, in the largest takeover so far this year. The proposed takeover will create a 20,000-mile network stretching across the continent, from the port of St John on Canada's Atlantic coast to the Mexican port of Lázaro Cárdenas on the Pacific. (FT)

UK-EU close to agreeing financial services forum The two sides are poised to agree a “talking shop” for co-operation on financial services, but the deal will leave the City of London facing barriers to trade with the 27-member bloc. The EU financial services commissioner is due to meet Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey on Monday. (FT)

Professional services staff burnout Soaring demand for legal and corporate advice during Covid-19 and a shift to remote working has resulted in mental health problems among junior workers, sparking fears of an exodus from the biggest law and advisory firms.

  • BlackRock has gained international renown as a champion of good corporate behaviour, including by fostering a more diverse workforce. But the asset manager is under attack by employees past and present who say the company has failed to provide a welcoming environment for people of colour. (FT)

Marsh & McLennan's role in Greensill Credit Suisse's internal review into Greensill Capital's collapse is pointing the finger at Marsh & McLennan, the world's largest insurance broker, according to people familiar with the matter. Marsh was the supply chain finance group's commercial insurance broker, responsible for finding cover against non-payment by its borrowers.

Saudi Aramco to maintain dividend Saudi Aramco stuck by its $75bn dividend pledge despite a 44 per cent drop in 2020 profits after the pandemic triggered lockdowns and travel bans that slashed oil demand, caused crude prices to tumble and weakened margins in its refining and chemicals businesses.

  • Low-rated US energy companies have raised more than $20bn in high-yield bond markets this year, the most since records began in 1996. (FT)

No US-China breakthrough The Biden administration and China ended their first high-level meeting on Friday after two days of talks in Alaska that produced an extraordinary public spat and no sign of improved relations between the powers. (FT)

The day ahead

US-UK trade talks US trade representative Katherine Tai is likely to hold a call on Monday with her UK counterpart Liz Truss. A trade deal would give the UK considerable headway in re-establishing trade relationships disrupted by its exit from the EU. (FT)

What else we're reading

Joe Biden's chance to end middle class stagnation Once every generation or so, America's social contract changes. After half a century in which capital has been in the driving seat, Joe Biden has a chance to tilt the advantage back to labour, writes Edward Luce. (FT)

Britain's housing supply must increase Food and shelter are essential requirements of human existence and, as the latter is almost as important as the former, the cost of housing often becomes a political issue. That is the situation in the UK. So what is the reality, and why, asks Martin Wolf. (FT)

Apollo-Athene: the new Berkshire Hathaway? If Warren Buffett's conglomerate provided refuge in 2008 to companies whose crisis-inflicted injuries did not condemn them to bailout or failure, in 2020 that role fell to Apollo, the investment group that two weeks ago announced a merger with its insurance affiliate, Athene. But stock market scepticism persists. (FT)

The risks and rewards of Elon Musk's self-coronation Andrew Hill is no fan of title inflation, or the parallel trend for weird C-level inventions, from chief fun officer to vice-president of mindfulness. But the Tesla chief's decision to anoint himself “technoking” has a serious side: Musk has added fuel to speculation about the company's long-term interest in bitcoin. (FT)

Crisis in the Himalayas An explosive cocktail of climate change and aggressive road and dam building in the geologically unstable mountain range threatens the people, economies and security of the eight countries in the greater Hindu Kush Himalayan region. (FT)

What is the secret of a successful MBA application? The FT spoke to a panel of admissions experts for their best advice and insights on how to create a compelling MBA application. Four students reflect on their experience of studying for a business course as the FT publishes its 2021 list of the best online MBAs. (FT)

Europe's fastest growing companies The FT also publishes today its annual ranking of Europe's fastest growing companies, including a new leader with a focus on renewable energy. The listing also demonstrates the appeal of tech. (FT)

Podcast of the day

The digital graduate The pandemic has put the education sector into overdrive, and accelerated the way we use technology to study. The FT's San Francisco correspondent Patrick McGee speaks to edtech innovators who are rethinking traditional degrees and a trucker who learned to code, in the latest edition of the Tech Tonic podcast. (FT)
